channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Kerry Urges Israel and Palestinians to Avert Breakdown in Peace Talks
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry emphasized that the leaders of both sides bore the ultimate responsibility for salvaging the negotiations.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Ukraine Implicates Ousted President in Shooting of Protesters
item.description: The Ukrainian authorities said on Thursday that former President Viktor F. Yanukovych had been involved in plans that led to the deaths of more than 100 people.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: Letter From Europe: Turkey Turns Its Back on the E.U.
item.description: After months of increasingly authoritarian rule by Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the E.U. portals seem more than ever to be closing on Turkey.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Supporters Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey at an election rally last month.

item.title: TV Duel in Britain Seen to Favor Anti-European Party
item.description: Opinion polls suggested that Nigel Farage — leader of the Independence Party, which wants to quit the European Union — had emerged as the winner in a debate with Deputy Prime Minister Nick Clegg.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Bomb Goes Off Near Former Pakistani Leader’s Convoy
item.description: The blast did not cause any casualties to the security convoy of Pervez Musharraf, who was being transported from the hospital to his home in Islamabad, where he is facing corruption charges.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: China Leans Toward More Stimulus Measures
item.description: As the economy shows signs of further slowing, government officials are making clear their willingness to step in.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: As Leaders Meet, Report Describes Chaos in Central African Republic
item.description: The report by Human Rights Watch offered evidence of killings in remote areas where atrocities are rarely chronicled.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: In Afghanistan, a Campaign of Resilience
item.description: Barring last-minute catastrophe, Afghans will vote on Saturday with a turnout that the United Nations hopes will reach 50 percent.
item.dc:creator: By BRYAN DENTON

item.title: Hunt for Jet’s Black Box Is a Race Against Time
item.description: Only days are left before the batteries on the flight data recorders on the missing Malaysia Airline jet are set to die.
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE
item.media:description: A crew member abord a Royal New Zealand Air Force flight holds a canister to launch a GPS marker buoy so an object in the ocean be tracked by satellite in the search for the missing Malaysia Airlines jet.

item.title: India Ink: Gujarat Experiments With Expansion of Public Health Insurance
item.description: The state has expanded its insurance plan for its poor in recent years, but critics say the insurance covers too few and relegates patients to substandard government health care.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL EDISON HAYDEN
item.media:credit: Sami Siva/Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting
item.media:description: Yasin Mirza, an auto-rickshaw driver, after undergoing a triple bypass surgery at V.S. Hospital in Ahmedabad, Gujarat, in February.

item.title: Japan Cancels Whale Hunt Off Antarctica After Ruling
item.description: The hunt is not widely popular in Japan, but it is backed by nationalistic lawmakers who paint opponents as trampling Japanese culture.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Zoo Teams Up to Highlight Animal Mistreatment at Shows
item.description: Animals Asia Foundation has found an unlikely host for its latest exhibition highlighting cruelty to animals in performances.
item.dc:creator: By SHAOJIE HUANG
item.media:description: Posters from an exhibition in Beijing designed to highlight the cruelty of animal performances.

item.title: Robert Slater, Journalist and Author, Dies at 70
item.description: Mr. Slater covered Israel for Time for two tumultuous decades and wrote more than two dozen books.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM YARDLEY

item.title: China Extends Tax Break Program to Spur Economy
item.description: China’s cabinet decided to continue the breaks for small and very small enterprises through 2016 and said it was considering significantly broadening them.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Syria Accuses Rebels of Planning Gas Attack
item.description: In a letter to the United Nations, Syria said that opposition groups were planning a toxic gas attack in a rebel-held area near Damascus so they could blame it on government forces.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS
item.media:description: A part of Aleppo, Syria, that activists said was hit Wednesday by a government airstrike. Syria is charging in a letter to the United Nations that opposition groups are planning a toxic gas attack near Damascus so they can then blame the government for it.

item.title: DealBook: A Muddy Tract Now, but by 2020, China’s Answer to Wall St.
item.description: A largely empty expanse in Shenzhen is the setting for a financial experiment that could have a huge impact on the world’s second-largest economy. But so far it is just a bold blueprint.
item.category: Bank of New York Mellon Corporation|BK|NYSE
Bank of New York Mellon Corporation
item.dc:creator: By NEIL GOUGH
item.media:description: The Qianhai special economic zone in Shenzhen

item.title: Deposed Ukrainian Leader Calls Crimea Annexation a ‘Tragedy’
item.description: In a tearful interview from Russia, Viktor F. Yanukovych said he would try to negotiate with President Vladimir V. Putin the region’s return to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: World Briefing: Japan Says It Will Abide by Whaling Ruling
item.description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said Wednesday that he would comply with an international court order to halt Japanese whale hunts off Antarctica.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: World Briefing: Ex-C.I.A. Official Defends Actions After Benghazi Strike
item.description: The former deputy director of the C.I.A. said he was not pressured to edit the widely debunked talking points on the 2012 Benghazi attack in an effort to protect President Obama and former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Pakistan: Musharraf Barred From Traveling Abroad
item.description: The Interior Ministry has rejected a request from former President Pervez Musharraf to go abroad for what he contends is a chance to seek medical treatment and to see his ailing mother.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Italy: 24 Suspected of Secessionist Plot Are Arrested
item.description: Special operations forces arrested 24 people Wednesday who were suspected of planning a violent independence campaign for the wealthy northeastern Veneto region.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Israel: Foreign Ministry Strike Ends
item.description: Employees of the ministry on Wednesday announced the end of an unprecedented strike over pay and working conditions that had shut the offices and 103 missions abroad for over a week.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: World Briefing: Greece: Immunity Lifted for Lawmakers
item.description: Greece’s Parliament on Wednesday voted to lift the immunity of another four of the Golden Dawn party’s lawmakers so they can face trial on charges of setting up a criminal organization.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: In Bullet-Ridden Afghan Districts, Free Vote Seems an Empty Promise
item.description: As the body count for Afghan security forces has risen, it has become clear that no one is going to vote on Saturday in embattled districts like Charkh.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: Soldiers at an Afghan Army command center for election operations in Charkh District. Officials say it is unlikely anyone there will come out to vote on Saturday.

item.title: NASA Breaks Most Contact With Russia
item.description: The space agency suspended contact except over operations of the International Space Station, underscoring the rapid deterioration of ties in the wake of the Kremlin’s annexation of Crimea.
item.dc:creator: By KENNETH CHANG and PETER BAKER
